Oh shame to thee, Land of the Gaul!</br>Oh, shame to thy children and thee!</br>Unwise in thy glory, and base in thy fall,</br>How wretched thy portion shall be!</br>Derision shall strike thee forlorn,</br>A mockery that never shall die;</br>The curse of Hate, and the hisses of Scorn</br>Shall burthen the winds of the sky;</br>And, proud o'er thy rule, for ever be hurl'd</br>The laughter of Triumph, the jeers of the World!

Oh, where is the spirit of yore,</br>The spirit that breathed in thy dead,</br>When gallantry's star was the beacon before,</br>And honour the passion that led?</br>Thy storms have awaken'd their sleep,</br>They groan from the place of their rest,</br>And wrathfully murmur, and suddenly weep,</br>To see the foul stain on thy breast;</br>For where is the glory they left thee in trust?</br>'Tis scatter'd in darkness, 'tis trampled in dust!

Go, look through the kingdoms of earth,</br>From Indus, all round to the Pole,</br>And something of goodness, of honour, and worth,</br>Shall brighten the sins of the soul:</br>But thou art alone in thy shame,</br>The world cannot liken thee there;</br>Abhorrence and vice have disfigur'd thy name</br>Beyond the low reach of compare;</br>Stupendous in guilt, thou shalt lend us through time</br>A proverb, a bye-word, for treach'ry and crime!

While conquest illumin'd his sword,</br>While yet in his prowess he stood,</br>Thy praises still follow'd the steps of thy Lord,</br>And welcom'd the torrent of blood;</br>Tho' tyranny sat on his crown,</br>And wither'd the nations afar,</br>Yet bright in thy view was the Despot's renown,</br>Till Fortune deserted his car;</br>Then, back from the Chieftain thou slunkest away—</br>The foremost to insult, the first to betray!

Forgot were the feats he had done,</br>The toils he had borne in thy cause;</br>Thou turned'st to worship a new rising sun,</br>And waft other songs of applause;</br>But the storm was beginning to lour,</br>Adversity clouded his beam;</br>And honour and faith were the brag of an hour,</br>And loyalty's self but a dream:</br>To him thou hadst banish'd thy vows were restor'd;</br>And the first that had scoff'd, were the first that ador'd!

What tumult thus burthens the air,</br>What throng thus encircles his throne?</br>'Tis the shout of delight, 'tis the millions that swear</br>His sceptre shall rule them alone.</br>Reverses shall brighten their zeal,</br>Misfortune shall hallow his name,</br>And the world that pursues him shall mournfully feel</br>How quenchless the spirit and flame</br>That Frenchmen will breathe, when their hearts are on fire,</br>For the Hero they love, and the Chief they admire!

Their hero has rushed to the  field;</br>His laurels are cover'd with shade—</br>But where is the spirit that never should yield,</br>The loyalty never to fade!</br>In a moment desertion and guile</br>Abandon him up to the foe,</br>The dastards that flourish'd and grew at his smile,</br>Forsook and renounc'd him in woe;</br>And the millions that swore they would perish to save,</br>Beheld him a fugitive, captive, and slave!

The Savage all wild in his glen</br>Is nobler and better than thou;</br>Thou standest a wonder, a marvel to men,</br>Such perfidy blackens thy brow!</br>If thou wert the place of my birth,</br>At once from thy arms would I sever;</br>I'd fly to the uttermost ends of the earth,</br>And quit thee for ever and ever;</br>And thinking of thee in my long after-years,</br>Should but kindle my blushes and waken my tears.

Oh, shame to thee, land of the Gaul!</br>Oh, shame to thy children and thee!</br>Unwise in thy glory and base in thy fall,</br>How wretched thy portion shall be!</br>Derision shall strike thee forlorn,</br>A mockery that never shall die;</br>The curses of Hate and the hisses of Scorn</br>Shall burthen the winds of the sky;</br>And proud o'er thy ruin for ever be hurl'd</br>The laughter of Triumph, the jeers of the World!</br>
